thread.title: North East firms say EU trading still vitally important
thread.title_full: North East firms say EU trading still vitally important

author: Coreena Ford
title: North East firms say EU trading still vitally important
text:
North East firms say EU trading still vitally important Maintaining close trading links with key European customers and suppliers is a must for the region's firms Share A European Union flag in front of Big Ben (Photo: Daniel Leal-Olivas/PA Wire) Share Get business updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
North East firms want to maintain a close trading relationship with their key European customers and suppliers, a survey has revealed. 
The British Chambers of Commerce’s (BCC) International Trade Survey includes views from the region’s business community and shows that future trading relationships with the EU are a high priority. 
Within the region, 75% of respondents sell and source goods and services in the EU market and more than a third are planning to put additional resources into exporting to the European market over the next five years. 
Ben Powick, policy adviser at the North East England Chamber of Commerce, said: “North East businesses continue to see the EU as integral to their export plans. Read More MPs could be given just five days to debate the UK's Brexit bill 
“Although the Government has outlined some of their key Brexit priorities, the future trading arrangements with the EU remain unclear. Despite this, North East companies continue to see Europe as key, with well over a third looking to put additional resources into the market. 
“In terms of our trading future relationship with the EU, tariffs are the top priority, with North East business prioritising tariffs, expensive non-tariff barriers and public procurement regulations to be at the top of the agenda for our future EU trade deal.” 
Internationally, over a quarter of North East businesses are looking to put more resources into exporting to North America. Similarly, 23% are looking to put more resources into Australasia, 22% to China and 21% to the rest of Asia (excluding India). 
Meanwhile, North East business consider tariffs, non-tariff taxation, and public procurement regulations as the three top priorities for resolution in a Brexit deal. Like us on Facebook
